If a beer isnt reflective of its marketed style, but still tastes pretty good  can you really fault it? Thats the case with Cigar City Hotter Than Helles Lager as it really isnt to spec as far as traditional guidelines go, however, it does the job its supposed to. This is indeed a clean, refreshing, drinker-friendly lager than pairs with warm weather perfectly. Thats not something I get to say about a beer reviewed in January until I moved to Florida.

I poured a 12oz can into a tulip glass. It was canned on 10/22/15 and a six-pack cost $8.99 ($1.50 per can or $0.12 per ounce). 

Appearance: Pale, lemony yellow hue with a slightly cloudy body. Initially pours to a large, white, soapy head but it fizzles away quickly and completely leaving no lacing.

Smell: Pretty standard lager aroma with a hint of lemon, though very mild overall. Nothing off-putting at all.

Taste: Id imagine if this beer were judged against other Dortmunders and Helles brews it probably wouldnt fair well as its missing that distinct pilsner grain and spicy noble hop character. However, as a generic pale lager it works quite well. I have a feeling theyre using American hops in here since theres a noticeably citrusy taste, especially of lemon and maybe grapefruit. Theres even a faint trace of tartness to be found, in fact it might even be lacto. That being said, I dont find it distracting as it complements the citrusy components just fine. This would be a great transition brew for macro drinkers.

Drinkability: Considering that Cigar City is a Florida-based brewery and the majority of their market is in warm-weather climates, it makes sense that Hotter Than Helles would be marketed as a liquid refresher. And it definitely works as such: the mouthfeel is thin and crisp, but quite refreshing across the tongue. It finishes completely clean. At 5% ABV its arguably sessionable, especially considering its affordably priced and comes in cans. I found it difficult to drink just one.

RATING: 7/10

If you think a Helles Lager should be hazy, with a head that vanishes in 10 seconds, and tastes like squeezed sour grapefruit, then this "beer" is for you. And, if you are an alcoholic, this beverage is your cure. 

On the other hand, if you have tasted really great helles lager in Prague or Munich, you will be very disappointed with this beverage. It is rather apparent Cigar City used lactic acid to ramp down the pH as the tart notes are clearly there. I suspect the step mashing on this beverage eliminated the proteins needed to form a good retaining head. 

No surprise Cigar Citys site indicates it is not in production (my sample was canned on 12/02/15). I suspect they knew it was a lousy beverage and decided they had to cut and run. But not until they put this awful thing on the market instead of sending it to the vinegar factory.

Other than a collaboration beer I had a few years ago that I dont remember the name of, this is my first CCB brew. And a good thing that its a light lager, because its a very difficult style to make really well. If a brewer can make a good, clean, vibrant hell or pils, thats really saying something...not so much an imperial stout or double IPA, which suffer flaws much easier. And on top of all that, I am especially fond of German lagers and have visited the country many times to quench that thirst. So this seemed like an excellent brew to sorta pre-judge forthcoming CCB products that will be rolling out here in Colorado. The result? Well, its somewhere in between disappointing and surprising. Its not as bad as feared, but not as good as hoped. Its kinda syrupy sweet, its kinda fizzy, and its not terribly clean. It just seems like not all that much love went into this...which is sad, because the best helles Ive had have been mind-blowing. On the other hand, it *does* have some aromatic allure, a nice floral hop bouquet thats thankfully not Americanized. In a blind tasting, you might indeed think it came from Germany. But in the end, its just kind of...well...uninspired. Compared to a hundred random pale lagers from Germany, this would be middle-of-the-road...which is pretty good for a young American brewery, no doubt. Hopefully their ales will fare better.

It finished slightly bitter. Certainly a good beer for hot, sunny South Florida Summers.

This one poured a clear bright yellow color with a fluffy white head.  Aroma was light grass, some earth, light grain, adn cracker.  Flavor was mainly cracker, light dough and refreshing german hops.  Very nice for the style.
Clear yellow. White head. Lemon,apricot and bread aroma.More body than I expected.Slightly sweet, a little bitter. The flavor is mild.Something like a medium white wine with carbonation.Good.

Can from Total Wine Tampa. Pours a well carbonated golden color with a small lively head. Aroma is of cereal malts, cracker, biscuit and light grassy bitterness. Taste is slightly watery, lots of sweet cereal malts, grain, bread crusts, mild bitterness in there also. Definitely a good gateway craft.

12oz can from pineypower, thanks bro. Poured cloudy light straw body with an average sized bubbly bright white head. Aroma is basically all bready malts, wet toast with a hint of vanilla. Medium bodied with strong carbonation and a quicker to average duration on the finish. Flavor up front is older malts, lots of grains with wet bread and on the very end is a touch of veggies.

Yea I am refusing to decant this out of the fun can it came in. This is a smooth malt kiddie ride and I like it, I could imagine these going down like water on a canoe trip and thinking to myself I am glad I am not drinking a bunch of shitty adjuncts and supporting megalomaniac super monopoly mega conglomeration corporation. This style doesnt scream pizazz and I am far from an expert but I feel quality in this brew and I like Greek people. Peace.

Basic aroma and dirty gold pour with a simple but balanced taste and mildly warming mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Jan 29 on can poured on Mar 6. Pours a light golden from the can into a pint glass. Not much head or retention. Smells of light fruit with a standard lager aroma. Light mouthfeel with low carbonation. Sweet light fruit and not much to get excited about. Par for the style and easy summer drinking. Just cant get into the style.

12 oz. can from a trade with a buddy on that other website. Lager glass shows me a hazy gold. Nice retention. Nose is sweet pale malts with light grain. Flavor is some sweet malt / bread notes, light corn flavors. Tad of dry bitterness on the backend. This has lots of sweet malt with nice balanced bitterness. This compares with the best German brews of this style. Really easy to drink.

Pours a hazy light straw golden color with a finger or so of fizzy foam that disappears quickly. The nose is full of doughy malts, noble hops and a trace of citrus. The palate follows the nose nicely with some heavy grainy dough, granny smith apple, grassy hops and a touch of cream corn.

Sort of like a really good budweiser. Didnt like it as much as i thought but it is definitely quality, just not my style. I like the hoppy notes and strong lager taste but there is something about it that doesnt make it my favorte. Seems like it should be an easy drinker yet is filling. Fair lacing and head. Straw colored. Does smell very good though. Crisp palate
Very nice offering from Cigar City....pours cloudy straw out of the can.  Not much of a head.  Taste in nondescript, but delicious.  Too sweet to be  lager..but not at all bitter...good stuff..

12oz straight from the can. Very sweet but not the sticky sweet that comes from corn syrup. Not much in the way of hops, but a bit of bitterness on the backend to balance out the brew. Very good session and another winner from CCB.
Pours clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is of grass, malt and a little metallic - typical of how I perceive lagers. Taste is clean, malty, medium-light bodied with some Hops. Nice balance.

Clear and fizzy yellow from the can. Aroma of grass, hay, and dandelion. Some malt aroma present as well. Lots of carbonation provides more mouthfeel than body. Light malt flavor, low bitterness, and dry earthy finish.

Loud can; nearly clear, light gold, creamy white head with marble-sized bubbles which go gritty on the sides of the glass. Pleasant, pilslager aroma.  Clean, malty, nicely bitter.  Above average lawnmower beer. Medium to lightish body, long bitter finish. ABC, Betton. Enjoyed with the first venison loin that I ever grilled. Thanks, Shep.

12 oz can from MeadMe. Thanks, dude! Ive been pumped for this thing. Pours a richer well hazed straw hue, lighter gold, firm haziness with gentle glow that grows. Frothy whitish head atop dies to a ring and laces small. Aromas are bready malts, straw, and grass. A touch of yeast, spice, mellow spice and earthy hops grow. Straw, gentle graininess, grass. Initial is lighter end of the fold, touch of body with firm grainy malts, bread, and straw. Gentle bready sweetness, touches of grassy hops meet gentle spice, yeast. Middle is bready, mellow sweetness, grass, bit of farm grain sweetness. Backend shows touch of lemon, grass, nice earthy hopping shows a bit of dryness, bitter earth hops. Straw, gentle dough, grainy malts, some bread. Finish is mellow, a touch metallic and dry earthy hops are firm. Touch of toasty dry grain, bready and straw elements, grass. Fun sessioner. Good flavors, a decent clean quality with touches of spice, yeast, earthy hops. Solid canned offering as far as a lager.

Cigar City Hotter Than Helles has that distinctive CCB signature and it doesnt disappoint.  Nice frothy head and clear yellow color.  Fruity, bready aroma with malty taste with just the right amount of hops. HTH is a refreshing drink that goes down easy with the taste lingering long after the last sip.
12 oz can...Beautiful hazy lemon color along with doughy lemon flavors and a clean dry finish...this Florida lager beats the Helles out of its German counterparts.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Bloomington, Indiana, USA

text: Draft. Pours golden/orange with pillowy head, maintains good lacing. Grass and lemon notes, with a bit of grain. Has an unpleasant and distinctly metallic flavor... imagine if I had this again with no metallic flavor I would really like it.
Awesome helles lager. Sweet and slighly malty. Heavy on the palate. Cloudy, light head.

From a 12 oz can at Avon NC.  Pours a cloudy lemon yellow with a  sight white head.  Aroma of bread dough and lemon follow through to the flavor.  Some biscuit notes in there as well.  Cirsp clean finish with just a hint of tartness.

Can from GOT, shared with Stanley Eisen.  Pours a nice cheddar orange with a nose of doughy malt and light floral hops.  Flavor Is a cascade of biscuits and grassy hops in a pile of light lemon water.  Decent mouthfeel.  Love the name of this beer.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
On tap at the Winter Warmer 2012, this pours golden with a wispy head that leaves similar lace. The nose is of grains and light vegetal notes. Flavors are substantial, of grains, lemons and mixed citrus with a clean finish. Substantial yet not cloying nor heavy. Really great Helles. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sixer from Total Wine. Pours golden under a thumbnail of pillowy white head with good retention. Aroma of soapy yeast. Grains, crisp green apple, subtle banana, aftertaste of biscuit. High carbonation and light body. Refreshing, easy drinking brew.
Draft.  Clear apple juice body atop small white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, orange, bread, some lemon.  Taste is medium sweet, straw, orange, some bread, lemon.  Light body, light effervescence.
Enjoyed at the CC Tasting Room. Light yellow with a large head.  Tatsy, both sweet and sour. Like a dirty blonde, with a chile pepper finish.  OK drinkability.

Can thanks to beernads.  Hazy yellow pour.  Sweet aroma of lemon citrus, graham cracker, wet pale malt, and hay.  Flavor is relatively sweet cracker malt and lemon drops and mild bitterness.  Actually very drinkable and decent, but a little sweet.

Can and served in standard pint glass: pours a clean straw hue with a moderate fizzy and and minimal lace. The aroma has notes of sweet bread and light handed spicy grassy hops. A hint of veggies also noted. The taste is what is expected of the genre, a slightly sweeter version of a pilsener. This a bready sweet and has minimal hop presence with a hint of hop spice and earthy notes. The mouth feel is appropriate but does have a "soapy" like finish. It is okay, would much rather have a fresh Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold or Back Road Millennium Lager. (Keyword: Uber Fresh)

12oz can---> Goose Island stemmed glass.  Pours a light golden yellow with a fluffy white head that sticks around for a bit and leaves pretty good lace.  Aroma is sweet grains and mild grassy funk.  Taste pretty much follows aroma with a wee bit of hop bitter at the end.  Light fizzy, kind of dry palate.  This is my first of this style, so I have nothing to compare it to, but I would gladly drink another.

12 oz. can from LetsPour. It pours a yellow/gold color with a decent sized white head. The aroma is very bready with only a hint of floral hops and grapey fruit. The flavor is white grape, bread, hint of floral hops. Nice mild bitter finish. Very sessionable. Tasty helles, but not as dry and fruitier than traditional examples. Hop character is appropriate.

Can. Pours hazy butterscotch with a small fizzy white head that dissipates quickly but does leave some lacing in its wake. Aroma is grain, grass, light corn syrup and light hoppy citrus. Flavor is about the same, lightly sweet with a grassy finish. A bit tangy, almost citric zesty on the finish. Light-plus body, prickly carbonation in the mouth. Pleasant.

On draft at Churchkey in D.C.

The beer is transparent and pale yellow with a half inch of white head. A fine appearance. The aroma is subtle, with notes of bread, grain, a touch of yeast. Smells good. The taste is more aggressive. Light and bready. Refreshing and crisp with appropriate carbonation. A solid example of the style.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 07-04-2012
How does from a can, nice golden color, nice lacing, and a decent amount of head. As for taste, has a bitter finish.

Can.  Thanks to adnielsen for sharing.  Pours a clear golden color and white head.  Pils malts, earthy, noble hops aromas.  Grainy, earthy, straw flavors.  Pretty good helles, but....OVERRATED.... OVERRATED

Canned @ home, courtesy of my Secret Santa. Thanks! Pours a clear, golden yellow appearance with a white head that doesnt have the best retention. Cracker, straw, grainy pale malty, light lemon aroma- good but fuck man, this aint world class. Dry herbal straw, hay, slightly chewy pale malty, cracker, easy drinking flavor. Pretty easy drinking but fuck man, this aint world class. All you fuckers that rated this world class need to try Wolnzacher or Gänstaller. Now that shits world class.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 Can from Total Wine, Naples. The pours a light gold color with a medium head that quickly fades. The nose is white bread, some honey and white grape. Simple aroma. The taste is sweet bread, light white apple, some honey. A touch of grain. Smooth, crisp. Good for what it is.

Aroma is wheaty and full, but not stale. Has a nice sweetness. Color is yellow with a sizable head consisting of white large bubbles. Taste is wheat and bitter, with some light doughyness. Has a little sour edge too. Not too watery and not too thick in the palate, but maybe a little too filling - perhaps too much so to enjoy as a light summer beer.
Tap at Cigar City. Clear light gold pour with a spotty white head. Excellent in its style - doughy, with a smooth palate.
Can to pint. Looks solid; light gold with white lacing. Smells and tastes doughy and a little bitter. Average on the palate. A solid example of the style.

12oz can, purchased from Leukens Liquors. Pours a bright golden color, high clarity; fine-bubbled white head with modest retention and lacing. A toasty Pils malt character in the aroma with a touch of spicy hops on the perimeter; clean ferment; definitely on-point for the style. Medium-light to medium body; m-high carbonation; crisp and toasty profile overall, and perhaps the most dialed-in American Helles Ive had: toasty Pils malt roundly expressed, a restrained but juicy perimeter of mineral and spicy hops, and a clean, well-lagered profile; an impressive, traditionally minded Helles that Id love to try head-to-head with something like Weihenstephaner Original. Lasting, toasty and cereal finish.
From the can.  Aroma is light, clean malt with biscuit and some minimal floral hops.  Taste is clean, dry malt with a bit of sweetness and light hop bitterness.  Clean, easy drinker.  Nice.

The aroma is fruity and malty with a floral type hop. The appearance is golden with a foamy head. The taste is like the aroma but is watery and has a chemical finish. The palate is average. Overall nice aroma but boring beer.

Canned, plenty of yeast floaters, taking away from the clarity. Sweet aroma, but balanced flavor. A bit of a clash between the malt sweetness and the bitterness. Despite being ice cold, not as refreshing as the name implies. Overall a bit dull.
Sabe a sour dough, fresh cold cuts, Welchito, fresh barley and hops. La mejor de Cigar City. The perfect lager!

Pint at Freshcraft. Pours with a clear golden hued body with a medium sized white head. Aromas are bready and toasty grain, lightly grassy. Clean yeast wise. Flavors are bready, clean, lightly sweet malt. Grainy, low hop, light sulfur. Lively bubbles, dry, crisp, quenching. Good solid beer, but not the best Helles I had GABF weekend. Still a good drinking beer.
Tap at Rossis. Gold, two finger white head. Nose and taste are yeasty bread, crackers, straw, hay. So clean and smooth and refreshing.

Tap. Moderate grain note of grain for the malt, light to moderate herbs for the hops, with hints of pepper and wood. Head is average size, frothy/creamy, white with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear pale amber. Flavor starts slightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then the long finish is lightly acidic and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery with a lively carbonation and a dry finish. Nice and mellow, this is an excellent version of a Helles.
Pours and smells like a lager - nothing much to speak of. A little apple in the aroma. Nice taste - slightly fruity, a little spicy, very light. Good session beer.

Pours a light gold with a thin white head. Aroma of bready yeast, slight citrus and nice malt profile. Light and easy drinking. Quality take on a classic style

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clean golden and frothy white head. White bread, orange, clean. Bit of citrus. Light bodied but enough flavour. Great lager. (On tap at the brewery)
(1 qt growler filled under pressure) pale gold with white head. Light malt aroma. Flavor is bready, light malt. a little light fruit and hay.
Draft at brewery. Nice nose with a crisp, refreshing taste. Great lager. I could drink this all day long. Hurry up and can this!

Sample at Redlight Redlight. Murky dark yellow pour with a thin white head that evaporates steadily. Spotty lacing on the glass. The aroma is sweet malt and yeast. Light-bodied with flavors of bready malt, yeast and floral hops. The finish is fruity with a grainy malt aftertaste lingering. Decent all around.

Draught at the brewery. Bready, crackers, light green apple aroma. Light straw color. small white head. Light sweetness. Final goes smoothly from bitter to sweet. Thin body and very smooth. Well-made.

Draft at Railroad Street.  Pours pale gold with 1-finger well-retained white head.  Nose is pale malt, hops, mild fruit.  Tastes smooth, crisp, with pale malt, hopcitrus, and some finishing fruit and peppery notes.
Taps and Tequila. Looked like a Bud and only tasted tad better. No aroma. Standard lager

Draft at Pegs Cantina. 

Pours pale golden yellow color thats very faint and watery.  Looks kind of like coors light actually with a 1.5 finger frothy headthat slowly settles into a lasting ring.  The glass is left coated with sheets of soapy lace.  The color of this beer isnt very appealing but the head has good retention and ample lacing.

Sweet yet slightly earthy aroma with hints of light fruit, straw, grass and pale malt.  Subtle bready presence with hits of apple and pear as well as some spicy, grassy hops.

Medium bodied but fuller than expected especially considering the appearance.  Light crisp hops followed by some earthy grass/straw character as well as some bready yeast and light fruit.  Some apple and pear provided sweetness that counters the earthy hop character.  Well balanced, light and very easy to drink.
On tap at Churckey for the Funky Buddha and CCB event. Big fruity notes with herbal doughy angel food cake. Medium body with a caramel malt oriented finish.

My Bottom Line :  
This grainy Helles moves into herbal hops before sharing a few odd green grape notes. 

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A ring of foam disappears into the cloudy blond.
-The watery mouthfeel doesnt have any elegance.
-I dont know if the bar is responsible for such a flat mouthfeel, but this doesnt help the brew one bit.
-Grain flavors are lengthy.
-This is flavorful, dont get me wrong, but it has none of the polished maltiness and fluffy mouthfeel I associate with the best examples of the style.

On tap at Blind Tiger, NYC.

Pours a murky golden yellow on tap with little head or lacing. Aroma is of belgian yeast and citrus, a little spiciness. Taste is light and nice; a little bit of buttery taste, but mostly follows smell. Good summer beer.

Well balanced very drinkable brew. Aroma and Flavor both have a light crisp bitterness along with a solid malt backbone but not too heavy at all. Not my favorite style I would say, the hop used is more of that grassy earthy hop I dont love but this was solid.

Draft pous hazy straw yellow, minimal head but what is there has fair staying power. Light nose of cracker and faint flower. Taste is malt centric with flowers on the finish. Light to medium bodied, one i could down on my deck all day. Name fits the bill for how hot rattle n hum was.

Draft at Rattle N Hum.  solidly hazy yellow in glass.  Thin head.  Nose is lost in the din of rabid/drunken soccer fans who insist on screaming at the TV screens.  Malt centric as expected. Slick and easily a standard session.  Alcohol is lost in the malt.  Finish has some lingering hop tone.  A touch of diacetyl that takes nothing from this solidly presented beer.
Draft. Pours gold with a small head. Aroma is faint and grassy. Taste is pretty earthy. This is Okay.

Shared by Ibrew2or3.  Pours a hazy golden color with a soapy white head.  Aroma is hay and grass.  Maybe some bready notes.  Taste is sweet with some light bitterness.  Medium bodied.  Plenty of flavor, but not my style of preference by a mile.
Helles! so good and fresh, reminds me of chilling out in Munich, very tasty brew.

Pours a hazy pale yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma has light straw and grassiness.  Flavor is wonderfully balanced with malty straw notes that fall just short of sweet and nice grassiness and faint earthy spice.  Mouthfeel is medium/full and very creamy with a crisp grassy/straw finish.  Very nice!

Draught at TJs:  Aroma of malt, grain, and a hint of honey.  Poured light yellow/straw in color with a small, creamy, dense, white head that diminished but lasted throughout as a film on top of the beer, as well as around the edges.  Hazy.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is slightly sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, grain, bread, and straw.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, grain finish is dry.

At Ginger Man NY
Aroma mild, grainy character, slight hint of grassy hop. Dry top end. 6+
 Appearance  clear, golden brew with medium fine white top.
Flavor and Palate : medium bodied. delicate, soft  malty with chewy walls. Good gentle hop dose. Drinkable proper to style Helles. Aroma maybe bit too dry, rest very solid interpretation.

Pale gold with good,creamy, white head / Nose of bread and citrus / Light to medium body, acidic and lively, with good balance and finish / Earthy but bright flavors of lemon, straw, lemon, and resin / Very nice and lively.

Tap at Ginger Man. Tap at Ginger Man. Grainy crackery aroma with a touch of light dustiness and a bit of soft pale malt. A touch of straw flavour as well. A touch of noble flavour.  Decent but kind of simple.

Big thanks to markwise for shipping us this 32oz swing top growler that arrived in perfect shape. It pours near hazy gold with off white head. The aroma delivers some what wheat like notes as well as esters of soft apples and peaches followed by slight malt graininess in the background. The taste is refreshingly yummy with some sweetness being filled in quickly by a fresh light wheat note followed by some fruity esters like apples and peaches and then a light sense of fresh grainy maltiness. This is just yum and refreshing and oddly nourishing all at the same time and makes me want to drink a ton of it. Well done Helles that steers clear of the trouble areas for me for this style. Nice one Ben!!!
Very smooth. Light in color.  Very very low in hop bitterness. Extremely drinkable!!
Draught at Ginger Man. New York. Clear yellow/golden - white head. Light malty. Toasted. Light citrus. Fruity. Bread notes. Nice pleasant. Light candlewax.

Aroma of bread, champagne and slight bubblegum.  Pours blonde and slighly hazy with good carbonation.  Taste is initially standard import lager but theres a sweet bready kick once it settles.  The yeast is a little more sour than I like but still a HIGHLY drinkable helles.

A predominantly grain laced aroma comes off of the nose with a crisp taste that opens to straw and a tiny bit of citrus. Smooth and balanced. Just a fantastic Helles. In my opinion one of the finest American offerings of this style.

From notes. Pours a golden honey color with very little head that disappears pretty quickly.
Sweet malt, a little citrus. Another person reviewing mentioned corn tortilla chips and am totally picking up on it.
Nice first sip, a little bitterness, some sweet malty notes, again some corn flavors, and a bit of spice.
Mouth feel is smooth and crisp, full carbonation, medium light body. Super drinkable, cigar city please start canning this guy.

Pours a bright yellow with a pure white head.  Little hazy.  The aroma is full of earthy hops and mildly sweet malts.  The flavor is not complex, but it is wonderfully balanced and complete.  Crisp, short finish.  Very refreshing.
Draught from the tiger. Pours gold. Faintly straw and apples aroma. Similar taste.
Cloudy gold/yellow pour with a nice white head.  Great crisp, tart, yeasty, lemony aroma.  Crisp, tart, clean delicious beer.  Loved it.
golden color, aroma is earthy, grain, toast, flavor is the same, crisp clean finish good for the style
Pours a gold yellow with a white head and aroma of wheat an malt. Taste is sweet and light with flavors of wheat, malt, grains, and citrus with a nice clean, crisp finish. Solid lager from CCB.

Tallahassee, FL - Fermentation Lounge - on tap. Dark gold pour - thick, frothy snow white head. Fresh lager aroma, hints of fresh lake water, a touch of wet paper. Aroma has some nutty accents, toasted bread, some raw dough sweetness. Mouthfeel is crisp and clean and sufficiently thick. Overall, a pretty solid entry.
draft at Cigar City, golden pour. very well made, flavorful helles. sweet. grainy, light grass. Nice mouthfeel. Nice

sample at Brewvival on 2/25/12. golden pour with a small white head. cereal / grain nose with some earthy hops. med body with more grain notes and light bitterness. sweet crisp finish. very enjoyable.

Draught @ Brewvival.  Clear golden pour with a fizzy white head.  Aroma was bready malt and spicy hops.  Flavors were incredibly crisp and refreshing.  Light, pretty and simple.  Well balanced and rounded out.  Very dry and yet I say again, Crisp.

Sampled at Brewvival 2012. Clear yellow with fair white head. Grassy aroma.  Flavor was sweet, verging on cloying, a little corniness.  Lingering semi bitterness.  I guess this is a decent example of the style, but I didnt particularly care for it.

Served on draft at Brewvival 2012. Pours slightly hazy gold with a medium frothy offwhite head. Decent head retention. Aroma of sweet grainy notes, grassy finish. The taste is grain, corny notes, cereal, grassy finish. Medium bodied.
Clear gold pour and small white head. Nose sweet, sweet malt and orange blossom honey. Sweet malty mouthfeel with slight mineral finish. Delicious and refreshing.
Tap @ Redlight Redlight. Pours clear copper amber eith a nice small white head. Aroma is sweet malty, honey, floral. Flavor is similar, nice bitterness. Finishes sweet bitter and malty.

Big mug poured at red light red light... Pours a semi-hazy earthy brown pour and topped with a thin lsoaoy white head... Aroma of sweet honey and pale grain. A light spice and vanilla. Sweet toasty malts... Flavors offer more of the same with shy herbal sweetness toasted grain and a moderate sweetness throughout. Easy drinking with a touch of dry bitterness on the backend.
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Grains and straw in the aroma, with light earth and mineral-like notes. The flavor is grainy, with a touch of sweetness, earth, and straw. Nice and refreshing.

Growler.  Yellow-gold with a thick white head.  Cereal, grain, bread, and herbal notes in the aroma.  Sweet bready flavor with corn and a light herbal hop character.  A little on the sweet side but a simple and refreshing beer to kick back to.

On tap @ Blind Tiger for CCB event Feb 1 w James and Streets. Wasnt a huge fan of this beer due to a medicinal, buttery sort of flavor, but it had a nice, slightly grainy texture and smelled floral/herbal. Too weak of a style in terms of abv for me to really pay enough attention - make a few ops jokes, look down, and the glass is almost empty, Served in shaker.
We lay on the rocks, in the sun, watching you and your mama row in.  I sat up and blinked when you appeared, so pale you were nearly clear.
A really solid, biscuity clean helles with mild sweetness and some light herbal hop quality.

Tap at Abraxas-ok, i rated this beer with a cold so I will definately need to re-rate this beer at a later date.  However, even with my congested state, i was able to say this about it-pours lite orange with a fizzy white head.  nose of sweet malt grains, spritzy hops with a touch of itallian spice.   flavors have sweet grains but enough dry spicy hops to balance this out.  lite crisp body with a long grainy finish.  I would have tons of these on a hot Miami day!!!

Pours yellowish golden from the tap, with a white head. Love CCB, I found it flat and watery, but than again I just cannot bring myself to lager land, and knowing CCB probably there dortmunder beer belies my rating and taste.
Very smooth and Lots of Flavors. Had on tap at the brewery in Tampa. Excellent beer.

Tap at Redlight Redlight and later at House of Beer in Orlando, FL. Pours a very clear, bright straw with a tight, thinner, white head. Decent retention and small lace. Nose is a bit grainy with small fruity peach and hints of diacetyl/butter. Great body: fresh, mild coconut, and peach atop full biscuit maltiness. No soap. No butter. Very impressive. Palate is quenching and super clean. As it warms the body gets a little earthy grain and hints of white vinegar. Mildly lactic palate. A very good attempt at a difficult style. Would like to see CCB do more stuff like this vs. imperial stouts and scotch ales.

Draft at Brass Tap: Poured a orange color with white head. Aroma is clean with dough bread and malt. Taste is smooth with more of that yeast bread and nice sweet maltiness. Very drinkable and refreshing.
Dried grasses, bread, biscuit, and a little dog food in the aroma.  Pours straw yellow.  Flavor of light malts, ready and crisp.  Low hop profile.  Light and refreshing.
On tap at redlight.  Light yellow with a foamy white head. Scent is malt and bread. Taste is balanced and smooth
This is just a superb easy drinking beer perfect with a burger or hoagie. Light and tasty, crisp and clean.
Big white head, clear pale golden, nice lacing... grassy flavor, mild grassy aroma, mild light malty profile... not very crisp...
on tap-pours a white head with trailing lace and yellow color.  Aroma is sweet grain/light malt-bready.  Taste is sweet grain/light malt-bready, secondary spice hops.

Lightly hazy dark golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of toast, citrus, toffee, hay, and light vanilla. Taste of straw, citrus, toast, toffee malts, and a dry finish.

On tap in a shaker.  Pours golden with a small, white head.  Aroma of sweet pale malts, some caramel and bread, plus floral, bitter hops.  Flavor about the same.  Smooth texture, and thicker than most of this style.  A good beer for the style.
Pours a bright yellow color with a thick white head. Nice pale malt aroma, lightly sweet with a solid hop bite! Clean and crisp, very comparable to schlenkerla helles.

Draft. Pours blonde with a fluffy white head, good retention/lacing. Aroma of cereal grains, lager yeast, lemon, citrus hops, fruity esters. Taste is lots of cereal grain, citrus, light lager yeast. Palate is clean, soft, creamy, light-bodied, lightly bitter finish. Definitely a stand out for the style and extremely sessionable.

Draft at World of Beer.  Pours a clear golden yellow color with a thin white head.  Minimal lacing.  Aroma is honey sweet with some bready malt notes.  Flavor is also sweet with some cereal notes.  Slight hop bitterness in the finish.  Crisp, clean and easy drinking.  Nice.

On draft at WOB Coconut Creek. Cant believe I havent tried this one yet. Good aroma of soft fruit such as bananas with a touch of creme and wheat. Flavor is geared more towards the fruit, somewhat like a hefe. Pretty good stuff.

Draft @ Treasure Coast beer fest. Pours slightly hazy straw color with white head. Fruity and grainy aromas. Slghtly sweet fruity flavor with dough and some cereal grains and light hops. Light to meduim body with crisp carbonation. Nice and refreshing.
On tap at proof.  Light yellow pour.  Light malt and grain aroma.  Tastes are grain, corn, lemon citrus and wheat.  Well balanced, but not my thing.

Draft at Iron Abbey. Pours a clear pale gold with lots of head. Really nice aroma. Notes of sweet breads and some bubblegum pop. Taste is light, sweet, and finishes dry. Emphasis on a honeyed bread flavors. A lot of bounce in the taste gives it just enough complexity to go with the drinkability.  I have no idea why anyone would drink a macro lager if this was available.

On tap in the tasting room. Light gold pour with a thin white head. Nice big malt, bready with a nice note of noble hops. Noble hop bitterness comes through really nicely in the taste, too, with a nice light malt. Well balanced and a great session ale.

Review from notes at World of Beer - Fort Myers on 10/30/11. 

Poured on draft into a shaker pint glass. 

Appearance: Pours a medium straw gold with a 1 finger foamy snow white head. Nice lacing.

Smell: Sweet malt, citrus and a touch of hops. Very light aroma.

Taste: Sweet malt and earthy hops with a touch of citrus. Aftertaste is bittersweet and fruity. 

Mouthfeel: Light-to-medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: High drinkability. Quite smooth.

Overall: Good beer overall. Worth a shot if you see it on draft.
On tap at Capones. Hazy yellow pour with a small sized head. Bready, toasty, floral, some citrus in the tastes, and grassy. Not one of my favorite styles, but I found this one quite drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2012 Growler from OmegaX. Pours a nice bubbly orange. The smell is thick of spices, bread and hops. Again, bread and hops fill the mouth with a thick flavor that lingers into a sourdough/dry citrus aftertaste. Finishes pleasantly bitter and only a tad dry... overall refreshing. This beer is so incredible and drinkable - if you think you dont like lagers you need to try this at least once!

Awesome beer!! Didnt expect this one to be so good. Nose is Honey Nut Cheerios. Honey and sweet malts/grain entice the nose and make this one very enticing. Like fresh baked sweet rolls. Poured out a nice clear yellow with a nice white head. Taste was super refreshing. Honey and fresh baked bread notes make this one a winner. Slightly earthy/grassy hops balance it out nicely making this one a definite winner. I could drink 20 glasses of this and still want another one. Great!
A very peppery lager, suprising awesome balance of pepper and malt sweetness then bam dry finish

Draft Treasure Coast Beer Fest 2011 Pours mostly clear and yellow with a mid-sized, fizzy, white head. The aroma offers honey, bread dough and pale grains. Light to medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation. Honey sweetness is tamed by peppery hops. Short, crisp, clean finish. Drank this stuff all day at the festival. Excellent session beer.
Pours pale yellow with some head and lacing. Nose is fresh with bready slight floral aroma, first sip is very nice bright, clean, balance of malt and hops. Finish is great. Simple taste done well.

Draft @ ravenous pig.   Honey and fresh baked white bread on the nose. Pours gold with a thin white head and light cascading bubbles.  Crisp grassy hops with loads of honey malt and white bread.  Super fresh tasting and very bright.

Great tasting beer, pours and looks like a Lager, yellow and fizzy (ooh, did I just say that) but this beer tastes very good. At 5% its a drinker, very clean and crisp, so glad CCB are making these lower % beers as well as the fantastic higher gravity!

Draught pour in a pint glass.  Pours a clear straw yellow with a small head.  Aroma is of light malt and a bit of hops.  Flavor also smooth, almost sweet malt with a very mild hop characteristic.  Light straw or grassy flavors mix in also.  Definitely a smooth drink.

Aroma is of bready malts and a bit of grassy hops.  It pours a hazy yellow body with a bubby white head.  It tastes lightly sweet with a bit of bitterness from the hops to balance it out.  Overall this is a nice sessionable beer from CCB and one to return to again.

On draft at CCB.  Pours a nice hazy yellow color with a white head.  Nose is some malt, bits of grain, and hints of citrus and slight hops.  Flavor is similar- light malt, some citrus, some grain, and hints of corn sweetness.  Light in body, well-balanced, and amazingly drinkable.  For a Helles, this one has great flavor.
Draft at the source.  Light and bright yellow, medium white head.  Aroma of straw and hay, taste is mildy bitter with a bit of pepper.  Decent.

Pint poured at Cigar City a crisp yellow color with very little head.  Aromas of malt, yeast, grass, grain, a hint of citrus.  Tastes follows the flavor with a hint of wheat, very sessionable beer, would be great next to a grill or outside to tail-gait.
Pour is a hazy bright yellow thin white head. Smell is wheaty slight lemon and grass. Taste is malt light yeast slight citrus pretty good for a later.

9/24/11. On tap at BA Hunahpus. Slightly hazy yellow pour with a small off-white head. Nice malty aroma - grainy and a little corny with some cream in there. Nice malty and grainy flavor, again with a touch of corn and cream, some grass and apples. Very nice!

Came down for BA Hunahpu and to visit friends.  First place we stopped was CCB.  Felt like drinking quick (since I had baby in hand...dont judge me), so a lager was the perfect choice.  Poured yellow with white head, great mouthfeel and went down easy.  This is an easy drinking beer that would go great with wings while watching a game.
